Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, the aroma of chicken soup filling the air, when my granddaughter, Miriam, slid into the chair beside me. Her eyes were wide, uncertain. “Bubbe, how did you know what to do when you started something new?” she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I felt the familiar tug to share stories from my own youth, to offer the gentle, personal wisdom that only a grandmother can give. But as I reached for her hand, my phone buzzed—a reminder for the adult education class I was scheduled to teach at the synagogue in half an hour. The topic was “Transitions in Jewish Life,” and I knew several congregants were planning to attend, hoping for guidance rooted in Torah and tradition. I could see the hope in Miriam’s face, the same hope I’d seen in my students’ eyes so many times. My heart twisted as I weighed the needs of my family against my responsibility to my community, both expecting me to guide them through uncertainty. I sat there, torn, the clock ticking, unsure which path to take.
